title: Add rm -rf /
body:
I have seen API fuzzers using rm -rf / in query params.

I expect this request will blow up like the drop table thread but wanted to suggest it non the less

title: Niger, the country.
body:
Niger is a literal country in Africa.  A whole country.  And yet way too many systems block its name because it is close to another word that some people don't like.  Imagine being unable to talk about your own home country online!  This should IMHO be added to the Scunthorpe Problem section.  If not my favourite sentence:

> Dams and dykes retard water in Niger.

title: Add markdown injection
body:
Systems commonly used markdown for convenience when defining templates for emails or user messages, however markdown is often seen as benign and not properly escaped. I propose you add a section on markdown injection.

Here are a few things to include:

```
**this is bold**
*unclosed bold
_this is italics_
_unclosed italics
[this is a link](http://example.com)
[this is a link](javascript:alert(25);)
![An image](http://example.com/image.jpg)
---
* bullet point
```

You could also add '# a title` but that would currently break your formatting for comments in `blns.txt`, not sure if you currently have a way around this?

title: O'Connel@gmail.com
body: O'Connel@gmail.com  - an apostrophe in the first part of an email address is perfectly legal, opening all sorts of possible validation and sanitation issues. O'%20drop%20users%20table%20@gmail.com

title: Pip Module support
body:
moving `__init__.py` to the top level of the directory makes the top level a real package and not a namespace package. This allows a `setup.py` to import the files to the same directory.

this supports https://github.com/danggrianto/big-list-of-naughty-strings/pull/1 which is https://pypi.org/project/blns/

title: Fully automate dev setup with Gitpod
body:
This commit implements a fully-automated development setup using Gitpod.io, an
online IDE for GitLab, GitHub, and Bitbucket that enables Dev-Environments-As-Code.
This makes it easy for anyone to get a ready-to-code workspace for any branch,
issue or pull request almost instantly with a single click.

title: Add Java library
body: A Java (JUnit) annotation and a plain method to test naughty strings.

title: Add <!--<script> to the list of strings
body:
Following string should be on list of strings.

```html
<!--<script>
```

The idea here is that such a string would cause denial of service (JavaScript fails to load) attack on certain JSON encoders. For instance, consider the following HTML page.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<script>
var p = "<!--<script>"
// </script>
document.write("Script doesn't close!")
</script>
```

Putting `<!--<script>` in a string has an unusual property of making `</script>` not work.

Some JSON encoders (such as one in PHP) encode slashes which prevents `</script>` escape:

```
$ php -r 'echo json_encode("/");'
"\/"
```

This does nothing again `<!--<script>`

```
$ php -r 'echo json_encode("<!--<script>");'
"<!--<script>"
```

title: Add cpio magic filename TRAILER!!!
body:
https://entropymine.wordpress.com/2018/05/27/the-cpio-trailer-problem/ makes a great point, cpio gives special meaning to certain filenames. Add that to list.

I'm not regenerating the generated code because, frankly, they were already out of date, the build system is a hot mess, there's two different variants for creating the Go source, etc. Fixing all that would belong in a separate PR, and even more to the point would take some technical leadership & stating the vision; what's the scope of the project etc.

title: blns: Add CVE-2018-15120
body:
Thanks a ton for maintaining this repo!

CVE-2018-15120 is a DoS vulnerability in libpango's handling
of emojis. The added sample is known to cause an assert on
libpango versions 1.40.8 and potentially earlier.

I also updated `blns.json` using the in-repo script, which caused some other changes. Let me know if you'd like me to scrub them from this PR.

title: Arabic strings are not "naughty" for arabic websites
body:
I saw that the list has Arabic text, why is this considered "naughty" ?
for example all social media and most programming languages support utf-8 strings, which include Arabic.

title: JavaScript prototype pollution & Object properties
body:
I added two new sections:

### JavaScript prototype pollution

This is an attack where properties are added onto Object prototype, making them part of ALL objects, e.g.:

```
object.__proto__.isAdmin = true
({}).isAdmin // == true
```

In essence, any code containing `obj[a][b] = value` where at least `a` and `value` are user controlled are vulnerable, and many popular libraries have had this vulnerability found. More info: https://github.com/HoLyVieR/prototype-pollution-nsec18

my two naughty strings contain the standard naughty JSON with a __proto__ property, and a less likely but still possible attack where `obj[a][b][c] = value` is needed. the JSON keys are common names that are likely to break any application (items, data, attributes)

### JavaScript Object properties

those are properties on the default Object prototype that will cause issues in two cases:

1. Programmer writes `obj.<obj-method>()` on a user-controlled object (can crash if user supplies this method) -- the correct thing to do is `Object.prototype.<name>.call(obj, ...)`
2. Programmer uses `obj[key]` on a user-controlled object to check if a key exists - this will always be truthy for Object properties, but incorrect. This logic error can be a security vulnerability in some cases.

title: List currently doesn't contain "-NaN"
body: Some languages parse the string "-NaN" to float value NaN and this can cause problems in software in much the same way parsing "NaN" might.
